captions.text:
Those of you who&#39;ve been following me for a while, 
who own that mysterious van that&#39;s always parked

outside, will know that I am presently a father 
to very young children. Young children who have

to be settled down for bed every night, and 
since the patent office rejected my chloroform

security blanket concept, I have to make do 
with reading them children&#39;s books. Oh yes,

I&#39;ve acquired a lot of opinions on children&#39;s 
books. I bet the bloke who wrote Harold and the

Purple Crayon wasn&#39;t the one in charge of 
cleaning the playroom walls. And is it me,

or is the central theme of The Pout-Pout Fish 
that existential depression can be cured by

being forcefully sexually assaulted? Perhaps this 
is why I was drawn to The Plucky Squire, a debut

video game by a new indie studio centralizing 
the concept of a children&#39;s picture book that

comes to life. Not to be confused with The Pluck 
Esquire, which is a video game about a lawyer who

plays the ukulele. The fuck was that, Yahtz. 
Never mind. In universe, the Plucky Squire is

a series of children&#39;s books about Jot, a squire 
in a generic children&#39;s fantasy world who could

best be described with a word that means gutsy 
and tenacious in a slightly patronizing way.

One of those really annoying children&#39;s books that 
will use up an entire double-page spread on, like,

three words and a silhouette of a castle, and I&#39;m 
not asking everything to be Where&#39;s fucking Wally,

but I just don&#39;t think that can be economically 
sound. The game opens with us exploring Jot&#39;s

daily life in a top-down very Zelda 
1-esque sort of gameplay arrangement,

very convincingly drawn in a nicely animated 
ligne claire sort of style like a minimalist

Tintin book. He goes about what promises to be 
a pretty bog-standard day in his life: get up,

get sent on a quest by a good wizard with a severe 
disinclination to leave their house, kill about 19

goblins, and thwart the plans of the evil wizard. 
&quot;Thwart&quot; being a word used to describe what heroes

do to the plans of evil wizards and nothing else. 
But a wrench is thrown in the thwarting process

when the evil wizard reveals that he&#39;s discovered 
they&#39;re living in a children&#39;s book in which he

is destined to inevitably fail, and so, in an 
effort to rewrite the book to render himself

unthwartable, he casts Jot out of the book, 
into the cluttered bedroom of the book&#39;s owner,

where he becomes a slightly off-putting, fully 3D 
render of himself, like a minimalist Tintin movie.

Can Jot use the various objects he finds while 
exploring the child&#39;s desk to return to the

world of his book and more decisively thwart 
the—oh, he did that while I was talking. Yes,

we return to the book almost immediately but can 
now use the power to come and go from the book

to solve puzzles by manipulating the pages and 
fiddling about with the words. So on one page,

there&#39;ll be some text saying, &quot;A massive guard 
was blocking the way,&quot; and on another, it&#39;ll say,

&quot;A tiny ant was pushing a crumb,&quot; so if you pull 
out and swap some of those words around, you can

change the reality of the story and finally 
teach that arrogant crumb who&#39;s boss. That&#39;s

what I might hesitantly call the core puzzle 
mechanic of Plucky Squire. There are others,

about 300 of them to be precise, but more on 
that later. Plucky Squire is pretty visually

impressive; that&#39;s probably why my computer 
sounds like it&#39;s having an asthma attack when

I run it. The world of outside the book is nigh 
photorealistic, and the attention to detail on

all the paint pots and crafting supplies is jolly 
impressive. It&#39;s like I&#39;ve been shrunk down into

a little ant and forced to navigate that one 
table in PT with all the pills and shit on it.

The simplistic art of the children&#39;s book 
parts feels very authentically like something

a hack artist would scribble out to meet the 
Christmas deadline, and the transition from

2D to 3D gameplay is nice and seamless. It&#39;s 
also very solidly written with some good gags,

and it clearly took a leaf out of the Thomas 
Was Alone/Stanley Parable/Shawshank Redemption

playbook, i.e., that very few narrative 
experiences can&#39;t be enhanced by the

addition of a warm, reassuring narrator 
voice. Maybe if A Serbian Film had been

dubbed over by Morgan Freeman, all the baby rape 
would&#39;ve been a lot less harrowing. All in all,

it&#39;s very professionally put together. The Plucky 
Squire, I mean, not the baby rape. &quot;GOSH, THANKS,

YAHTZ.&quot; Whoa, don&#39;t get overexcited, Plucky 
Squire, you might spill something from that

massively overloaded tray of game mechanics you&#39;ve 
got there. And now we&#39;re getting to it. Let me be

clear—everything that comes from the premise of 
messing with a children&#39;s book to affect the story

is great. Replacing words, tilting the book to 
slide objects around, leaving the book and going

over to a Magic the Gathering card to secure 
a bow to bring back to the book, all on theme.

What&#39;s not on theme is when you bring the bow 
back and play a shooting minigame entirely unlike

the core gameplay up to that point. Or the one 
boss fight where you play Super Punch-Out!! Or the

one where you play Doctor Mario, or the one that&#39;s 
a rhythm game akin to those Rhythm Heaven games

the WarioWare devs used to make, or the mandatory 
stealth puzzle section that goes on too long; to

use the standard unit of banal timewasting, it&#39;s 
at about five TikToks. And what has any of this

got to do with children&#39;s books? Some of these 
minigames crop up when members of Jot&#39;s entourage

of support NPCs are given moments to shine, after 
which they go, &quot;I have completed my story arc!

Now I will join you in standard combat!&quot; And it&#39;s 
presented as significant, but it&#39;s fucking Zelda 1

combat. I never needed any help with it, and all 
they proceed to do is run around being annoying.

It&#39;s like when my kids insist on helping me 
make banana bread and just proceed to get

in the way and eat all the flour. The whole game 
culminates in a final boss fight outside the book

in which we strap on a jetpack and play fuckin&#39; 
Space Harrier against a giant alien butterfly.

Again, nothing to do with anything that&#39;s been 
set up, story- or gameplay-wise. I was waiting

for the book&#39;s owner to walk into the room 
and anticlimactically end things with a fly

swatter. God knows I&#39;m not saying a game can&#39;t 
have variety; the insipid Zelda 1-style &quot;poking

at sushi ingredients with a cocktail stick&quot; combat 
probably needs some, but it doesn&#39;t leave room for

the game&#39;s interesting mechanics to breathe. The 
&quot;swapping words around&quot; puzzle will occasionally,

if you&#39;re lucky, involve having to get words 
from previous pages in the same chapter, and

that&#39;s as complex as it gets. How about letting 
us leave the book and steal words from other

nearby books? Like, grab a few words from a copy 
of Fifty Shades of Grey and use them to embarrass

someone to death. I might slightly meanly call 
Plucky Squire a game with a bad case of &quot;first

game syndrome.&quot; So excited to be here and to show 
you all its ideas, like a child wanting to take

you to their room and show you their SpongeBob 
pillowcase, fittingly enough. Keen to show off all

the different minigames it knows how to make and 
reference all the old games that have influenced

it, and the end result is a game that is fun 
and competently assembled but which is spread

too thin to reach its full potential. It&#39;s like a 
rock song that never kicks in properly. A sensual

massage that has to end disappointingly when there 
isn&#39;t a spare power socket for the buggery drill.
